data.bodyText:
Hike 1 mile up the Navy Road to the Del Norte Trail junction and then follow the trail for .25 miles to an overlook of the northeast coast

Difficulty: Moderate

data.title: Devastation Trail
data.listingDescription: The Devastation Trail meanders gently through a landscaped covered in cinders from the 1959 eruption of Kīlauea Iki

images.altText: A man and woman walking on a paved path through a barren landscape covered by cinders
images.title: Devastation Trail
images.caption: Hikers on Devastation Trail

data.bodyText:
The Devastation Trail stretches from the parking lot at the Devastation Trailhead to Puʻupuaʻi Overlook,via a one-mile (1.6 km) round-trip walk on a paved path.

The area was blanketed in cinders from the 1,900-foot tall lava fountains during the 1959 eruption of Kīlauea Iki. The trail provides views of the new cinder cone, Puʻupuaʻi, that developed during the five-week eruption. Stay on the paved trail. Do not climb the cinder cone.


Endangered nēnē (Hawaiian geese) frequent this area. Please use caution when parking. Don't feed the nēnē.
data.audioDescription: A paved path through an area covered in rust-colored cinders and sparse vegetation

data.title: Cathedral Cove Hike
data.listingDescription: Beautiful rock formation, crystal clear water, kelp forests, sea caves, sea birds, and sea lions all may be seen from the Cathedral Cove overlook. Distance: .6 miles (round trip from visitor center) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: Overlooking a shallow bay from high on a cliff. White and grey seagull is perched on a rock.
images.title: Cathedral Cove
images.caption: Cathedral Cove

data.bodyText:
Beautiful rock formation, crystal clear water, kelp forests, sea caves, sea birds, and sea lions all may be seen from the Cathedral Cove overlook.

Distance: .6 miles (round trip from visitor center)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: For your safety, please remain behind the railroad ties on the ground. From the northern post for trail stop #3, you are at the edge of a steep cliff facing north across the Channel towards the mainland in the distance. The edge of the cliff is about two feet in front of you and drops several hundred feet straight down to the ocean. The cliff continues east and west along the full length of the island. At 8 o’clock, at the bottom of the cliff is a tall shallow cave filled with a small beach. There, you can usually spot tiny tan and brown lumps that are actually pinnipeds, a scientific family that includes seals and sea lions. They generally lay still and may be mistaken for rocks when seen from this far away. Every few minutes however, one or two will roll around, flap their flippers, or fight with one another. Their bellows can often be heard, even from this distance. At 9 o’clock, around a rocky outcrop, is another shallow beach at the base of the cliff. More pinnipeds are often seen there. Just offshore a kelp forest can be seen below the water, interspersed with patches of sandy ocean bottom. From 11 o’clock to 1 o’clock, Santa Barbara County can be seen on the distant mainland, across the channel. At 2 o’clock is Ventura County. At 3 o’clock is the white, cylindrical Anacapa lighthouse, about 6 stories tall.

data.title: Cavern Point Loop Hike
data.listingDescription: Not to be missed. Magnificent coastal vistas and seasonal whale viewing. To avoid a steep climb, hike clockwise, beginning from campground (near site #22) and looping back to Scorpion Anchorage. From Cavern Point, you may also follow the North Bluff Trail west for 2 miles out to Potato Harbor. Distance: 2 miles (round trip from Scorpion Beach) Difficulty: Moderate

images.altText: Yellow flowered plant with green leaves on top of steep cliff with ocean below.
images.title: Cavern Point
images.caption: Cavern Point

data.bodyText:
Not to be missed. Magnificent coastal vistas and seasonal whale viewing. To avoid a steep climb, hike clockwise, beginning from campground (near site #22) and looping back to Scorpion Anchorage. From Cavern Point, you may also follow the North Bluff Trail west for 2 miles out to Potato Harbor.

Distance: 2 miles (round trip from Scorpion Beach)
Difficulty: Moderate
data.audioDescription: The trail leads to Cavern Point, a high, windy barren plateau. This vast open landscape of compacted soils and sheer cliffs provides an experience of the ocean and surrounding geographic features in all directions to include Santa Barbara to the north, the islets of Anacapa and San Pedro Point to the east and to the south, Montano ridge rises up to 1808 ft. and last, to the west a twenty mile stretch down the coast of Santa Cruz Island.

data.title: Del Norte Campground Hike
data.listingDescription: Follow the rugged Del Norte trail east to the Del Norte Road and then head south to the backcountry camp nestled in a shaded oak grove with scenic views. Carry water. No water at this campground. This backpack camp is 3.5 miles from Prisoner’s Harbor or 12 miles from Scorpion Anchorage. Distance: 7 miles (round trip from Prisoner's Harbor) Difficulty: Strenuous

images.altText: Picnic table next to an oak tree on a hill overlooking the ocean.
images.title: Del Norte Campground
images.caption: Del Norte Campground

data.bodyText:
Follow the rugged Del Norte trail east to the Del Norte Road and then head south to the backcountry camp nestled in a shaded oak grove with scenic views. Carry water. No water at this campground. This backpack camp is 3.5 miles from Prisoner’s Harbor or 12 miles from Scorpion Anchorage. Make this hike a loop (8.5 miles) by continuing on the Del Norte Road south past the campground to the Navy Road and return to Prisoner's Harbor. The elevation gain up to to the Navy Road is worth it as it provides sweeping views including a view of the south of the island

Distance: 7 miles (round trip from Prisoner's Harbor)
Difficulty: Strenuous
data.audioDescription: This small campground contains 4 sites that are nestled within oak trees and grasslands. They sit up on a ridge that provides sweeping coastal views of the island and ocean.

data.title: Lighthouse Hike
data.listingDescription: View the last permanent lighthouse on the west coast that was constructed in 1932 on East Anacapa Island. Distance: .5 miles (round trip from visitor center) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: Lighthouse near cliff with ocean and clouds.
images.title: Anacapa Island Lighthouse
images.caption: Anacapa Island Lighthouse

data.bodyText:
View the last permanent lighthouse on the west coast that was constructed in 1932 on East Anacapa Island.

Distance: .5 miles (round trip from visitor center)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: LIGHTHOUSE AND FOG SIGNAL BUILDING Located on the highest and most eastern point of East Anacapa Island, the lighthouse and fog signal building are surrounded on three sides by steep cliffs. 11 miles of channel waters separate us from the mainland and its mountain ranges to the north and east. An easy walk up the dirt trail takes you to the lighthouse. The coast guard operates the lighthouse. For safety reasons, visitors are not permitted to tour the lighthouse, or fog signal building. The next two paragraphs describe the lighthouse and fog signal THE LIGHTHOUSE The lighthouse is 39-foot concrete cylindrical white stucco tower in the Spanish Revival style. At the entrance is a red portico and steel door. Three rectangular windows are at various levels along the sides and eight rectangular windows wrap around the tower near the top. The tower is topped with a railing that encircles the glass lantern room with diamond-shaped window panes. Behind the glass cylinder is the solar powered acrylic lens. The original Fresnel lens (pronounced (fray-nel) is on display in the Visitor Center. THE FOG SIGNAL BUILDING Next to the lighthouse sits the fog signal building. This 16 square foot, one story, white stucco building has a flat roof of terra cotta clay tile topped with a small, chimney like, white tower. The tower creates a second tier that houses the signal equipment. Metal rods stick out the top of this tier and hold the two signal horns. Solar panels are mounted to the back of the building.

data.title: Lobo Canyon Hike
data.listingDescription: A spectacular canyon with wind- and water-sculpted sandstone cliffs, a year-round stream, riparian vegetation, and a spectacular coast at its mouth. Well worth the effort. Distance: 9 miles (round trip from pier to canyon mouth) Difficulty: Strenuous

images.altText: Visitor walking in narrow canyon with steep walls.
images.title: Lobo Canyon
images.caption: Lobo Canyon

data.bodyText:
A spectacular canyon with wind- and water-sculpted sandstone cliffs, a year-round stream, riparian vegetation, and a spectacular coast at its mouth. Well worth the effort.

Distance: 9 miles (round trip from pier to canyon mouth)
Difficulty: Strenuous
data.audioDescription: You are standing on a dirt road in a canyon, surrounded by rocky hills that are covered grasses that are often brown, with patches of grey-green scrub brush and coreopsis with thick branches topped with tufts of feathery green leaves and yellow, daisy-like flowers in springtime, and a shaggy, brittle, brown mop of dead leaves in the drier seasons. Near the start of the trail, small trees are clustered along the bottom of the canyon. A wooden sign on a wooden post reads, Lobo Canyon Trail Nearby, under some coast live oaks, with small oval grey-green leaves, are two picnic tables. As you start down the road, it narrows a thin trail, and the view dramatically changes. The canyon grows steeper and narrower, and greener and lusher along the canyon bottom. The trail passes under many oak trees, draped with lace lichen, which looks like long, thin, gray, lacy shawls of fabric, that drape down from the branches. Here, a variety of plants thrive, including toyon, with long green oval leaves and clusters of buds, flowers or red berries, depending on the season; willow, with a sweeping canopy of light green leaves that turn yellow in the fall; cattails, with tall thin green leaves, and brown cylindrical spikes shaped like broom handles; blackberries, with prickly green leaves; and horsetails, with tall hollow green stalks with ringed sections. As you descend along the trail, in many seasons, a stream will flow by your side, curving along just to the right of you. The shady oaks give way to shrubs and grassland bordered by magnificently carved sandstone cliffs. These steep tan-colored cliffs are made of horizontal layers of rock within a curving vertical face, as if a giant stack of pancakes, had been carved away with many spoons. Above the curved cliffs, the top layer of earth projects out, like a little lip. The hillsides above the cliffs have the same kinds of plants seen on the hills at the start of the trail, with the addition of coastal prickly pear, a broad cactus with grey and green pancake-shaped leaves covered with thorny spines and, in season, pear-shaped red fruit, also covered in spines. About half way down the trail, a side trail takes you to a cathedral-like side canyon, surrounded by the carved sandstone cliffs, with a bowl-shaped base, and many alcoves and caves to explore. As you go further down the trail, cool ocean breezes tell you when you're getting close to the beach. At the mouth of Lobo Canyon, the creek often forms a small lagoon just before the beach.

data.title: McGinnis Ferry Boat, Canoe, and Raft Launch
data.listingDescription: The McGinnis Ferry Launch provides access to the river for power boats, canoes, kayaks, rafts, and tubes. This launch has a rather small parking area.

images.altText: Looking straight down boat ramp with retaining walls on both sides and wood shoreline accross river.
images.title: McGinnis Ferry Boat Ramp
images.caption: If we had only brought the boat.

data.bodyText:
The McGinnis Ferry Launch provides access to the river for power boats, canoes, kayaks, rafts, and tubes. This launch has a rather small parking area.

Water Quality

Be sure to check the Current Estimated E. coli count before starting your trip. If the count at Medlock Bridge is greater than 235 you have an increased risk of getting sick. Contact with the river is NOT recommended.

Water Release Schedule

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are influenced on a daily basis by water releases from Buford Dam. The water release schedule can be obtained by calling (770) 945-1466, or toll free 1-855-DAM-FLOW (1-855-326-3569), or visit their Hydropower Generating Schedule website. Besides showing the time for scheduled releases it also shows how many turbines will be operating and the current flow in cubic feet per second (cfs). It takes approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes to 2 hours for water released from Buford Dam to begin rising at McGinnis Ferry.

River Flow Rates

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are also influenced by the weather upstream of McGinnis Ferry. Regardless of whether the water is coming from a dam release or inclement weather upstream check the discharge/flow rate at the gaging station 0.76 miles upstream of McGinnis Ferry, Suwanee, GA. 

  • If Canoeing, Kayaking, or Stand Up Paddleboarding and the flow rate is over 4,000 cfs, cancel your trip. 
  • If Rafting and the flow rate is over 5,000 cfs, cancel your trip.
  • Float tubes are discouraged on this stretch of the river due to cold water temperatures.

Try These Floating Options

  • Lower Pool Park to McGinnis Ferry: 8.3 miles
  • Settles Bridge to McGinnis Ferry: 3.8 miles
  • McGinnis Ferry to Rogers Bridge Park (Temporarily Closed): 2.9 miles
  • McGinnis Ferry to Abbotts Bridge: 4.5 miles
  • McGinnis Ferry to Medlock Bridge: 9 miles

data.title: Medlock Bridge Boat, Canoe, and Raft Launch
data.listingDescription: Looking for a place to launch a power boat for a day of fishing on the river or a canoe, kayak, or raft for a nice float on the river then this may be a good starting point.

images.altText: Looking down ramp with retaining walls on either side and wooded shoreline across river.
images.title: Medlock Bridge Launch
images.caption: Great place to launch any watercraft.

data.bodyText:
The Medlock Bridge Launch provides access to the river for power boats, canoes, kayaks, rafts, and tubes. During the summer this launch can be very crowded at times. Please be considerate of other users by moving your equipment off the launch area as soon as possible.

Water Quality

Be sure to check the Current Estimated E. coli count before starting your trip. If the count at Medlock Bridge is greater than 235 you have an increased risk of getting sick. Contact with the river is NOT recommended.

Water Release Schedule

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are influenced on a daily basis by water releases from Buford Dam. The water release schedule can be obtained by calling (770) 945-1466, or toll free 1-855-DAM-FLOW (1-855-326-3569), or visit their Hydropower Generating Schedule website. Besides showing the time for scheduled releases it also shows how many turbines will be operating and the current flow in cubic feet per second (cfs). It takes approximately 3 hours and 30 minutes to 4 hours and 45 minutes for water released from Buford Dam to begin rising at Medlock Bridge.

River Flow Rates

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are also influenced by the weather upstream of Medlock Bridge. Regardless of whether the water is coming from a dam release or inclement weather upstream check the discharge/flow rate at the gaging station at Medlock Bridge, near Norcross, GA. 

  • If Canoeing, Kayaking, or Stand Up Paddleboarding and the flow rate is over 4,000 cfs, cancel your trip. 
  • If Rafting and the flow rate is over 5,000 cfs, cancel your trip.
  • If Tubing and the flow is over 2,500 cfs, cancel your trip.

Try These Floating Options

  • McGinnis Ferry to Medlock Bridge: 9 miles
  • Rogers Bridge Park (Temporarily Closed) to Medlock Bridge: 6.1 miles
  • Abbotts Bridge to Medlock Bridge: 4.5 miles
  • Medlock Bridge to Jones Bridge Canoe (no trailer access): 2.1 miles
  • Medlock Bridge to Jones Bridge Boat: 2.4 miles
  • Medlock Bridge to Garrard Landing Park (no trailer access): 5.4 miles
  • Medlock Bridge to Island Ford (no trailer access): 10.2 miles

data.title: Mississippi: Tougaloo College
data.listingDescription: During the 1950s and 1960s, this historically black college became a primary center of activity of the civil rights movement in Mississippi. Students at Tougaloo, whose campus is located ten miles north of Jackson, led a multi-year effort to end racial discrimination in the state's capital city.

images.credit: By MS Dept of Archives and History - http://misspreservation.files.wordpress.com/2009/10/boddieca-19
images.altText: Black and white photo of a large mansion.
images.title: Tougaloo College
images.caption: Tougaloo College

tags: Discover our Shared Heritage Travel Itineraries
data.bodyText:
During the 1950s and 1960s, this historically black college became a primary center of activity of the civil rights movement in Mississippi. Students at Tougaloo, whose campus is located ten miles north of Jackson, led a multi-year effort to end racial discrimination in the state's capital city. The nine historic buildings on the campus date from the mid-19th through the early 20th centuries.

Tougaloo College was founded in 1869 by the American Missionary Association to provide teacher education and industrial training for African Americans in Mississippi. From its start Tougaloo College served all races; a white student was among its first graduating class. Tougaloo students and white students at the nearby Millsaps College, a white Methodist school, formed academic and social bonds, setting, for the time, a rare example of racial cooperation.

In 1960 Tougaloo installed a president who would lead the college through the turbulent years of the civil rights movement. Dr. Adam Beittel began a successful exchange program with several northern schools, including Brown University, which brought white students to Tougaloo. Because Tougaloo College was a private institution administered by a board in New York, it was free from State control. Students at Tougaloo began protesting racial discrimination in Jackson, and led a boycott of restaurants in the city which refused to serve blacks. Many students were arrested for protesting at the businesses and for trying to attend segregated white churches and concerts. President Beittel frequently bailed the students out of jail. The students also led a successful campaign to encourage white entertainers not to participate in segregated performances in Jackson. In the 1960s Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee members Bob Moses and James Lawson held voter registration and nonviolence workshops on campus.

Resistance to the civil rights activities of the students brought violence to the Tougaloo campus, as faculty housing on the edge of the school often became the target of drive-by shootings. In 1964 the Mississippi State Sovereignty Commission (created by the legislature to defend the state from the encroachment of federal authority) successfully prevailed on Tougaloo's Board of Trustees in New York to dismiss Dr. Beittel as college president by threatening trouble between the college and the State if Beittel remained. The Board removed Dr. Beittel, but by this time the student movement on campus was waning.

Tougaloo College has continually sought to enhance the education of its students, as well as to promote harmonious racial relations between whites and blacks. As the center of the civil rights movement in Mississippi, Tougaloo College played a vital role in advancing the black community in the State.

Visit the National Park Service We Shall Overcome travel itinerary to learn more about the civil rights movement themes and histories. Also, be sure to check out Civil Rights subject site.

A project through the Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) Grant Program, which helps preserve the historic structures on HBCU campuses, funded interior rehabilitation work on the John W. Boddie House at Tougaloo College in 2018.

quickFacts.value: Tougaloo College is located in the unincorporated area historically referred to as Tougaloo, Mississippi, ten miles north of downtown Jackson, just across the county line in Madison County, but within the city limits of Jackson.
quickFacts.name: Location

data.title: Johnson's Lee Hike
data.listingDescription: Johnson’s Lee serves as the gateway to backcountry beach camping which is available between August 15 and December 31. Both of these routes are long hikes with a considerable amount of climbing and is recommended only for the experienced, well-conditioned traveler. Distance: 28 miles via the Main Road; 27 miles via the South Road (round trip from pier) Difficulty: Strenuous

images.altText: Coastline with sandy beach and elephant seals.
images.title: Johnson's Lee
images.caption: Johnson's Lee

data.bodyText:
Johnson’s Lee serves as the gateway to backcountry beach camping which is available between August 15 and December 31. Both of these routes are long hikes with a considerable amount of climbing and is recommended only for the experienced, well-conditioned traveler.

Distance: 28 miles via the Main Road; 27 miles via the South Road (round trip from pier)
Difficulty: Strenuous
data.audioDescription: You are standing at the edge of a parking area, on a bluff above the ocean. At your feet, grass grows up through a thin layer of decomposed asphalt a hard-packed cement-like surface. Before you, facing the parking area and angled toward the ocean, is a beige two story building. It has clapboard siding and a gabled, or simple peaked, roof, covered with brown shingles. The front of the building has four white roll-up garage doors, big enough to accommodate a large truck. The three doors on the right are new, with aluminum panels. The door on the far left is older, made of a grid of wooden sections, six squares wide by seven high. At mid height, the squares are six windows, running horizontally across the door. The rest are wooden panels, with faded and peeling white paint. The right side of the building has a single story extension with a slanted, shed roof. The front of this extension has a metal door, and a sliding glass window. The side of the extension has three windows. A metal picnic table sits on the ground outside these windows. On a flat grassy area, near the building, on the right, or ocean, side, are three picnic tables. To the left side of the building, overgrown with scrubby bushes, is a second structure. It looks similar to a carport. The front of the building is open. It has cement walls on the other three sides. The back of the structure partially cuts into the gentle hill where it sits. A gabled roof is supported by three wooden poles. The roof is damaged and has a large hole on one side. Behind the buildings is a hillside blanketed in scrubby brush with patches of grass.

data.title: Philander Smith College and the 1957 Crisis
data.listingDescription: In 1957, Little Rock’s Philander Smith College, an historically black college, opened its doors to the “Little Rock Nine” to help them prepare for their first days as students at Central High School. Barred from entering the all-white high school by order of the governor, the students struggled to keep from falling behind in their coursework, aided by Philander Smith College faculty members.

images.altText: President Clinton and members of the Little Rock Nine at a Philander Smith commemorative service.
images.title: Philander Smith and the 1957 crisis
images.caption: President Bill Clinton is joined by members of the Little Rock 9 for a service at Philander Smith.

relatedParks.fullName: Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site
relatedParks.name: Little Rock Central High School

tags: little rock central high school national historic site
data.bodyText:
September 1957 

On the evening of September 2, 1957, the day before the schools were to open in Little Rock, Governor Orval Faubus appeared on statewide television and announced that he intended to surround Central High School with Arkansas National Guard troops because of “evidence of disorder and threats of disorder.”  Faubus said, 

“The mission of the State militia is to maintain or restore order to protect the lives and property of citizens.” 

Two days later, nine African-American students, the “Little Rock Nine,” attempted to enter the school, but were turned away by the troops. 

While the NAACP and the school board pursued the matter through the federal courts, all of the Nine were denied entry to the school for the next two weeks. During this time Philander Smith College opened its doors to the students. The faculty provided tutorial opportunities for the students to enable them to stay current with their studies and rejoin their white classmates. 

“Realizing that the dilemma of integration wasn’t going to be resolved quickly, everybody seemed to be concerned about our falling behind in our schoolwork. Teachers from our community along with other professionals were offering to give us books and to tutor us. It felt good to dress in school clothes and go to Philander Smith, our community’s college. For part of each day, I studied schoolwork and spent time with my eight friends, enjoying a thimbleful of normality.”

Melba Patillo Beals, Little Rock Nine

 

The Faculty Responds 

Dr. Ozell Sutton attended Philander College and graduated in 1950. He was the president of the Little Rock chapter of Philander Alumni. He recalled his involvement in tutoring the Little Rock Nine.:

“The subject of the tutorial was how do we get through this?  We learned strength, vitality, and throughout the civil rights movement that young people were our contacts with what ought to be. They (Little Rock Nine) forced me to act out my commitment...I learned how to struggle, and what it means to be committed...Philander was there, willing and ready to assist.” 

 

Philander Students Continue the Fight 

In March 1960, nearly 50 students participated in a sit-in demonstration at Woolworth’s lunch counter in downtown Little Rock. Store managers closed the lunch counter and five Philander Smith College students were arrested after refusing to leave. They were charged with loitering and with “creating a disturbance in a public place.” Chief of Police Eugene Smith reported that all five were “sitting there with their backs to the counter” reading books and magazines. 

George Howard, Jr., an attorney for the five students argued in court that the arrests were a violation of the 14th Amendment to the United States Constitution. He said that criminal laws should not be used to help private business owners deprive customers of equal treatment. 

 

September 1997  

In 1997, President Bill Clinton attended a candlelight vigil at Philander Smith College in observance of the 40th anniversary of the Central High desegregation crisis. In his speech, he stated, 

“...Parents and family members who were threatened with the loss of their jobs, neigh­bors who gave them everything from money to food to transportation and, of course, the faculty here at Philander Smith, who volun­teered to tutor them, [gave] an extraordinary gift. And I would say to all of you who were involved in that, they all turned out pretty well, and I thank you for that.” 

 

What Is An HBCU? 

Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) are postsecondary institutions that were originally founded for the purpose of providing educational opportunities for African Americans before and after the Civil War. 

Today, there are over 100 HBCUs, located in 20 states, the District of Columbia, and the Virgin Islands. They include accredited two- and four-year as well as graduate and professional institutions. 

 

Philander Smith Today

Philander Smith College was established in Little Rock in 1877 to provide educational opportunities for former slaves following the Civil War. The college was opened under the supervision of the Freedmen’s Aid Society of The Methodist Episcopal Church, and it was named Walden Seminary.  In 1882, Adeline Smith, widow of Philander Smith-an Illinois philanthropist-donated $10,500 to Walden Seminary. The school’s trustees renamed the institution Philander Smith College in recognition of this gift. Philander Smith College awarded its first baccalaureate degree in 1888 and became accredited by the North Central Association of Colleges and Schools in 1949. 

Today, Philander Smith College is one of four historically black colleges and universities in Arkansas and is affiliated with the United Methodist Church and the United Negro College Fund.  The college places special emphasis upon the importance of service among its faculty and students and encourages their participation in the greater Little Rock community.  Among its illustrious alumni, Philander Smith College includes Dr. Joycelyn Elders, former U.S. Surgeon General, Charles Adams, an inventor who developed the U.S. Postal Service sorting machine, and Huburt “Geese” Ausbie, former Harlem Globetrotter. 

A project through the Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) Grant Program, which helps preserve the historic structures on HBCU campuses, funded restoration and renovation work on the James Monroe Cox Administration Building at Philander Smith College in 2018.
data.audioDescription: Founded in 1877, Philander Smith College is a small, privately supported, historically Black, four-year liberal arts institution related to the Board of Higher Education and Ministry of the United Methodist Church and is located at 900 W. Daisy L. Gatson Bates Drive in Little Rock. The school campus is located in central Little Rock. Interstate 630 (the Mills Freeway) was constructed just north of the campus, which is bounded by 10th and 14th streets to the north and south, and Gaines and Chester streets to the east and west. The core of the campus was originally built for Little Rock Junior College (now the University of Arkansas at Little Rock), and a two-block section of it is listed on the National Register of Historic Places. One of its centerpieces is the former U.M. Rose School building, now the Cox Administration Building, designed by the noted Arkansas architect John Parks Almand in 1915, when he was working for Charles L. Thompson. The campus also includes the "Old Gym", a gymnasium built by the WPA during the Great Depression; and a former barracks building of the Camp Robinson Air Force Base, which was moved here in 1948.

data.title: Jones Bridge Boat, Canoe, and Raft Launch
data.listingDescription: Back your trailer down the ramp to launch your boat for a great fishing trip. Or launch your self propelled watercraft but please move your vehicle to the main parking lot that has plenty of parking spaces.

images.altText: Looking down paved boat ramp with fence topped walls on either side. Wooded area behind walls.
images.title: Jones Bridge Boat Launch
images.caption: It's a straight shot into the river to launch your boat.

data.bodyText:
The Jones Bridge Boat, Canoe, and Kayak Launch provides access to the river for trailered boats, canoes, kayaks, rafts, and tubes. The parking lot is small and only vehicles with trailers are allowed to park in the lot on weekends.

Visitors using canoes, kayaks, rafts, or tubes are encouraged to use the Jones Bridge Canoe and Kayak Launch accessible from the main parking lot. You may unload your gear at this launch but will then be required to move your vehicle to the main parking lot and walk 0.4 mile back to the launch. Parking along the access road is not permitted.

Water Quality

Be sure to check the Current Estimated E. coli count before starting your trip. If the count at Medlock Bridge is greater than 235 you have an increased risk of getting sick. Contact with the river is NOT recommended.

Water Release Schedule

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are influenced on a daily basis by water releases from Buford Dam. The water release schedule can be obtained by calling (770) 945-1466, or toll free 1-855-DAM-FLOW (1-855-326-3569), or visit their Hydropower Generating Schedule website. Besides showing the time for scheduled releases it also shows how many turbines will be operating and the current flow in cubic feet per second (cfs). It takes approximately 3 hours and 45 minutes to 6 hours for water released from Buford Dam to begin rising at Jones Bridge.

River Flow Rates

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are also influenced by the weather upstream of Jones Bridge. Regardless of whether the water is coming from a dam release or inclement weather upstream check the discharge/flow rate at the gaging station at Medlock Bridge, near Norcross, GA. 

  • If Canoeing, Kayaking, or Stand Up Paddleboarding and the flow rate is over 4,000 cfs, cancel your trip. 
  • If Rafting and the flow rate is over 5,000 cfs, cancel your trip.
  • If Tubing and the flow is over 2,500 cfs, cancel your trip.

Try These Floating Options

 

  • Rogers Bridge (Temporarily Closed) to Jones Bridge: 8.5 miles
  • Abbotts Bridge to Jones Bridge: 6.7 miles
  • Medlock Bridge to Jones Bridge: 2.4 miles
  • Jones Bridge to Garrard Landing Park (no trailer access): 3.0 miles
  • Jones Bridge to Island Ford (no trailer access): 7.8 miles
  • Jones Bridge to Don White Memorial Park (no trailer access): 10.2 miles

data.title: Jones Bridge Canoe and Raft Launch
data.listingDescription: You'll have to carry your gear to the launch but it's well worth the haul. Launch your watercraft from a step-down ramp and watch the last step into the river.
data.bodyText:
The Jones Bridge Canoe and Kayak Launch provides access to the river for canoes, kayaks, rafts, and tubes. You'll have to carry your gear from the main parking lot approximately 100 yards to the step-down ramp. The step-down ramp is 9 feet wide and has 19 steps that you will have to negotiate.

Water Quality

Be sure to check the Current Estimated E. coli count before starting your trip. If the count at Medlock Bridge is greater than 235 you have an increased risk of getting sick. Contact with the river is NOT recommended.

Water Release Schedule

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are influenced on a daily basis by water releases from Buford Dam. The water release schedule can be obtained by calling (770) 945-1466, or toll free 1-855-DAM-FLOW (1-855-326-3569), or visit their Hydropower Generating Schedule website. Besides showing the time for scheduled releases it also shows how many turbines will be operating and the current flow in cubic feet per second (cfs). It takes approximately 3 hours and 45 minutes to 6 hours for water released from Buford Dam to begin rising at Jones Bridge.

River Flow Rates

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are also influenced by the weather upstream of Jones Bridge. Regardless of whether the water is coming from a dam release or inclement weather upstream check the discharge/flow rate at the gaging station at Medlock Bridge, near Norcross, GA. 

  • If Canoeing, Kayaking, or Stand Up Paddleboarding and the flow rate is over 4,000 cfs, cancel your trip. 
  • If Rafting and the flow rate is over 5,000 cfs, cancel your trip.
  • If Tubing and the flow is over 2,500 cfs, cancel your trip.

Try These Floating Options

  • Rogers Bridge (Temporarily Closed) to Jones Bridge: 8.2 miles
  • Abbotts Bridge to Jones Bridge: 6.4 miles
  • Medlock Bridge to Jones Bridge: 2.1 miles
  • Jones Bridge to Garrard Landing (no trailer access): 3.3 miles
  • Jones Bridge to Island Ford (no trailer access): 8.1 miles
  • Jones Bridge to Don White Memorial Park (no trailer access): 10.5 miles

data.title: Pinniped Point Hike
data.listingDescription: This south side overlook between the visitor center and the campground provides incredible view of the lighthouse and the sea lion rookery below. Distance: .4 miles (round trip from visitor center) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: Steep, rugged brown cliffs with white lighthouse and green plants with yellow flowers on top.
images.title: Pinniped Point
images.caption: Pinniped Point

data.bodyText:
This south side overlook between the visitor center and the campground provides incredible view of the lighthouse and the sea lion rookery below.

Distance: .4 miles (round trip from visitor center)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: For your safety, please remain behind the railroad ties on the ground. The view: From the southern post for trail stop #3, you are at the edge of a steep cliff facing south toward the Pacific Ocean. The edge of the cliff is about ten feet in front of you and drops several hundred feet down to the ocean. The cliff continues east and west along the full length of the island. At 8 o’clock, are the red roofs of the Visitor Center and other buildings. At 9’oclock, Anacapa Island stretches eastward to a narrow tip, pointing toward the Santa Monica Mountains, in the distance on the mainland. Near the very end of the island is the white, cylindrical Anacapa lighthouse, about 6 stories tall. Far below, at the base of the cliff is a steep rocky shore, with small pockets of small cobble and sand beaches. There, you can usually spot tiny tan and brown spots lumps that are actually pinnipeds, a scientific family that includes sea lions and seals up to 16 feet long. Most of them lay still on the shore, and may be mistaken for rocks when seen from this far away. Every few minutes however, one or two will roll around, flap their flippers, or fight with one another. Their bellows can often be heard, even from this distance. At 10 o’clock, sea birds sit on a large rock just offshore. From here to 2 o’clock is the broad Pacific Ocean, with no other land visible. Boats are sometimes seen offshore. At 3 o’clock East Anacapa Island continues westward. The northern edge of Middle Anacapa Island is seen in the distance.

data.title: Historic Scorpion Ranch Hike
data.listingDescription: View the historic Scorpion Ranch complex dating to the late 1800s. Exhibit areas include an orientation kiosk, blacksmith shop, farm implements, and a visitor center located in the Scorpion ranch house. Distance: .5 miles (round trip from Scorpion Beach) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: field leading up to buildings surrounding by tall trees
images.title: Scorpion Ranch
images.caption: Scorpion Ranch

data.bodyText:
View the historic Scorpion Ranch complex dating to the late 1800s. Exhibit areas include an orientation kiosk, blacksmith shop, farm implements, and a visitor center located in the Scorpion ranch house.

Distance: .5 miles (round trip from Scorpion Beach)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: On the valley floor, within the protection of a wide canyon is the Scorpion Ranch housing complex that consists of a two-story ranch house with a kitchen, bakery with a built-in masonry oven, dining area and two rooms upstairs for housing ranch staff. A bunkhouse and a storage shed, about the size of a garage, are also within the 5-foot-high wooden split rail fence that surrounds the compound. Gardens, shrubs and fig trees edge the buildings. The two-story, adobe Scorpion Ranch house, now the visitor center with exhibits, is tucked in close to the canyon walls and faces the open valley to the south. The ranch house was built in 1886 of rubble-wall masonry and rests on a stone and mortar foundation. The building has a rectangular plan that measures 51 feet by 18 feet. It has a shed roof and walls that are 20 inches thick and composed of local stone, adobe bricks, mortar covered with white stucco, and limestone. Windows across the face of the building provide natural light. The first floor has two main rooms, both are open to the public with exhibits and audio visual components that describe the natural and cultural history of the area. The bakery is at the west end of the building and also contains exhibits. The bunkhouse is located immediately south of the adobe ranch house. Built in 1914, this one-and-a-half story wood frame structure has a simple, gable-roof and white board-and-batten siding.

data.title: Historic Ranch Hike
data.listingDescription: View the historic ranch buildings along this easy, flat walk ending at the main ranch house. Stop by the school house for exhibits on the ranching history of Santa Rosa Island.  Distance: .8 miles (round trip from pier) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: Two story wood ranch house with lawn in front.
images.title: Main ranch house
images.caption: Main ranch house, 2007.

data.bodyText:
View the historic ranch buildings along this easy, flat walk ending at the main ranch house. Stop by the school house for exhibits on the ranching history of Santa Rosa Island. 

Distance: .8 miles (round trip from pier)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: You are standing on a sandy dirt road, more than 300 feet long, running roughly east to west, from the ocean side near the landing dock road, toward the ranch barns. There are 6-foot high wooden fences on the north and south sides, creating a long, narrow corridor. To the east is a glimpse of the ocean. Toward the southeast, just beyond the fence, a long line of eucalyptus trees form a windbreak. The fences on the north side of this road, and some of the south side, are part of a series of ranch corrals. The corral fences are constructed of posts, with four wooden plank rails, each about one foot by twelve. As you walk west along the road, toward the ranch buildings, on your left, you will see a long pen that parallels the eucalyptus windbreak. About half-way down the road, on the left is another pen with a large water trough. At the far end, straight ahead, is a large corral, adjacent to a blacksmith shop barn. A little to the right, farther away, is a larger horse barn with a large corral connected to it. Turning around to return east, back along the same road toward the ocean, this larger pen feeds into smaller pens, ending with a row of six small pens connected by a narrow fenced corridor

data.title: Inspiration Point Hike
data.listingDescription: One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Not to be missed. Distance: 1.5 miles (round trip from visitor center) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: View of 3 islands in blue water with yellow flowers in the foreground.
images.title: Inspiration Point
images.caption: Inspiration Point

data.bodyText:
One of the most spectacular views in the park can be found from Inspiration Point. Not to be missed.

Distance: 1.5 miles (round trip from visitor center)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: Note: For your safety, please remain well away from cliff edges. You are standing at the narrow tip of a several hundred-foot cliff at the western edge of the island. The edge of the cliff drops off about ten feet in front of you and about 50 feet to your left. Toward 8 o’clock, about 20 feet to your left is a bench. Beyond the cliff’s edge is the Pacific Ocean with no other land in sight. At 12 o’clock, the rest of the Anacapa islets stretch out toward the west, rising and falling like a sea serpent swimming through the water. Pelicans and other seabirds dot the surfaces of these islets, cliffs, and the rocky shorelines. Middle Anacapa Island is visible, as is West Anacapa, and the landing there, called “Frenchy’s Cove.” Boats are often seen anchored off the cove. In the distance is Santa Cruz Island. From 2 o’clock to 3 o’clock, across the channel, is Santa Barbara County on the distant mainland.

data.title: Torrey Pines Hike
data.listingDescription: View one of the rarest pines in the world, the Torrey pine. The moderate route allows visitors to view the pines along the flat Coastal Road. The strenuous route follows the loop trail to the top of the grove, providing spectacular views. . Distance: 5 miles to base of pines; 7.5 miles via the loop trail (both are round trip from pier) Difficulty: Moderate to strenuous

images.altText: Lone tree overlooking bay with low tan hills.
images.title: Torrey pine
images.caption: Torrey pine

data.bodyText:
View one of the rarest pines in the world, the Torrey pine. Torrey pines occur naturally in only two locations in the world—on the cool, fog drenched northeastern slopes of Becher’s Bay and just north of San Diego. The easier, moderate route allows visitors to view the pines along the flat Coastal Road. The strenuous route follows the loop trail to the top of the grove, providing spectacular views. For the best route take the loop trail up the western edge of the grove, along the top, and down the steep, eastern side of the grove. For an easier, more gradual descent, follow the road down to Southeast Anchorage.

Distance: 5 miles to base of pines; 7.5 miles via the loop trail (both are round trip from pier)
Difficulty: Moderate to strenuous
data.audioDescription: You are standing high on a rocky hillside, overlooking a wide ocean bay, surrounded by tall Torrey pine trees. In the distance, the coastline curves out to Carrington Point. In the middle of that curve are a cluster of buildings at the ranch complex, and a wooden pier that stretches far out into the ocean. The Torrey pines have tall thin dark brown trunks have bark with a cracked surface, like a cracked pie crust or alligator skin. Overhead, the tips of branches end in clusters of long spikey dark-green needles—up to about 10 inches long. Growing on the branches are brown oval -shaped pine cones, made of dozens of splayed open seed scales with gaps in between them. The rocky, bumpy ground surface below the pines is blanketed with brown pine needles; a few twisted, dead pine branches; and fallen pine cones. Some pine cones have rolled downhill, and collected at the bottom of gullies. Below the trees are a few smaller plants: island manzanita bushes, with red branches and green oval leaves with bunches of berries that are green, yellow, or red, depending on the season. Scrub oaks, with small bush-like trees with grey bark, small olive green, oval shaped leaves, and, in season, acorns shaped like a smooth cone, with a knit beanie hat on top. Monkey flower, with green oval leaves and small red flowers. Underfoot, the rocky ground surface is covered with lichen, a pale green crust-like growth, that looks like blotches of spray paint. Above the trees, you can often hear the screech of red tail hawks. One may also find Allen’s hummingbirds—tiny, 3 inch long birds with fast fluttering wings, green backs, and purple throats. Sometimes you also find the colorful San Clemente spotted towhee, a large sparrow with a white-spotted black back and a black rump. Its breast is black, its belly white, and its sides are reddish brown. It has a black head with red eyes. Its wings are black with white spots and its long tail is black with white corners. As one heads south from the Torrey pine forest, a grassy hillside drops down toward low rolling hills, with sandy Skunk Point, in the distance.

data.title: Washington, D.C.: Andrew Rankin Memorial Chapel, Frederick Douglass Memorial Hall, and Founders Library at Howard University
data.listingDescription: Andrew Rankin Memorial Chapel, Frederick Douglass Memorial Hall, and Founders Library at Howard University in Washington, DC, were important settings for this institution's role in the legal establishment of racially desegregated public education.

images.altText: Three photos of brick campus buildings.
images.title: Frederick Douglas Memorial Hall
images.caption: Frederick Douglas Memorial Hall

tags: Discover our Shared Heritage Travel Itineraries
data.bodyText:
Andrew Rankin Memorial Chapel, Frederick Douglass Memorial Hall, and Founders Library at Howard University in Washington, DC, were important settings for this institution's role in the legal establishment of racially desegregated public education. Two nationally recognized leaders of that fight, Charles Hamilton Houston and Thurgood Marshall, were closely associated with Howard University. From 1929, Howard Law School became an educational training ground, through the vision of Charles Hamilton Houston, for the development of activist black lawyers dedicated to securing the civil rights of all people of color. 

Howard University also provided preparation of the legal strategy presented by Thurgood Marshall and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People's (NAACP) Legal Defense Fund leading to the historic decisions in Brown v. Board of Education ending segregation in education. The university represents the role that institutions of higher learning played in bringing about racial desegregation in education. Howard University led the country in the education of civil rights attorneys dedicated to legally securing desegregation, the academic research supporting the unconstitutionality of segregation, and the community outreach needed to challenge and define the interpretation of the United States Constitution in American society. No other university provided the same level of support to the desegregation fight.

The graduates of Howard Law School, Houston and other faculty, litigated many of the cases involving challenges in education. In fact, nine of the 10 lawyers who argued Brown were graduates of or professors at Howard Law School. The best known graduate was Thurgood Marshall, who, when appointed in 1967 by President Lyndon B. Johnson, became the first African American to sit on the Supreme Court of the United States. After obtaining his undergraduate degree from Lincoln University in Pennsylvania, Marshall graduated from Howard Law School in 1933 and immediately began his campaign against segregation, providing counsel in a host of civil rights cases. When Marshall became director-council of the NAACP Legal Defense Fund in 1938 he directed the legal attack on segregation at all educational levels, arguing successfully in Sipuel v. Oklahoma State Board of Regents(1948), McLaurin v. Oklahoma State Regents for Higher Education (1950), and Sweatt v. Painter (1950). Marshall served as lead attorney on Brown, capitalizing on his previous desegregation success. In addition to producing a cadre of civil rights attorneys through the law school, the university contributed to the preparation and presentation of the Legal Defense Fund strategy. Graduates of the university, arguing in groundbreaking litigation, looked to their alma mater to provide research, expert testimony, and legal critiques of their litigation efforts.
 

Visit the National Park Service We Shall Overcome travel itinerary to learn more about the civil rights movement themes and histories. Also, be sure to check out Civil Rights subject site.

A project through the Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCU) Grant Program, which helps preserve the historic structures on HBCU campuses, funded handicap accessibility renovation work on the Founders Library at Howard University in 2018.

quickFacts.value: Main campus of Howard University in Northwest Washington, D.C.

data.title: Skunk Point Hike
data.listingDescription: One of the most recognizable points on the island due to the extensive white sand beach. Opportunities to see snowy plovers, tidepools, and a shipwreck. Follow the coastal road until it meets up with the Skunk Point trail. Distance: 12 miles round trip (from pier) Difficulty: Strenuous

images.altText: Crescent bay leading to a sandy point.
images.title: Southeast Anchorage and Skunk Point
images.caption: Southeast Anchorage with Skunk Point in the distance.

data.bodyText:
One of the most recognizable points on the island due to the extensive white sand beach. Opportunities to see snowy plovers, tidepools, and a shipwreck. Follow the coastal road until it meets up with the Skunk Point trail.The back beaches and sand dunes between and including Skunk Point and just north of East Point are closed to hiking from March 1st to September 15th to protect the nesting area for the snowy plover, a federally listed, threatened shorebird. Please remain on the wet sand (below mean high tide) or the road throughout this area.

Distance: 12 miles (round trip from pier)
Difficulty: Strenuous
data.audioDescription: You are standing at Skunk Point, flat sandstone slab that stretches far out into the ocean, covered, inland, by an enormous white sand beach. The rock is a light, pinkish tan in color. Closer to the water, thin grooves or channels appear in the rock, running in the direction of the water. Near the mid-tide mark, the rock slab begins to break into smaller chunks and the surface is covered with bright green algae. Here at the point, various currents and ocean swells often collide, creating turbulent waters. Waves seem to break in various directions, creating crisscrossing lines of foamy white water. The water close to shore is a pale turquoise in color, changing to a darker blue farther from shore. Visible from the most commonly visited parts of the island, the triangular-shaped beach behind Skunk Point seems far larger in reality than it appears from a distance. Although its size varies with the seasons, the beach can be almost four miles long and almost a mile deep. The Skunk Point Marine Reserve begins to the east of Skunk Point and continues down to the southern tip of the beach. To the northwest is Bechers Bay, followed by Carrington Point in the distance. To the southeast is East Point. In good weather, Santa Cruz Island can be seen in the distance, to the east. There is an extensive back sand dune area along the beach which is off limits in spring and summer, in order to protect the nesting and foraging areas for the endangered western snowy plover. You are standing on a rocky shoreline. The stone is a conglomeration of sand and thousands of rocks, ranging from the size of a small nut to a small watermelon, that poke up from a smooth surface, creating a trip hazard, so please watch your step. As you move closer to the ocean, deep pools are nestled in gaps of the shoreline. One pool is the size of a small swimming pool. Near the mid-tide mark, the rock surface is carpeted with slippery, bright green algae. Seaweed with rubbery branching leaves, grips the rocks along the edges of the pools. The sea floor in the pools is mixed of sand, sandstone, and cobblestones, covered with a wide variety of animals. Among these may be ochre stars, which are orange, five-armed sea stars with white dots. Bat stars, orangish-red sea stars with five wide arms. Sea urchins, red, purple and black creatures with spiky needles radiating outward, like a spiky ball. Anemones, circular greenish animals surrounded by a ring of pale, pointy tentacles, that curl up into a tight ball if touched. California sea cucumbers, tan and bumpy cucumber-shaped creatures. Mossy chiton, a well camouflaged animal, with a hard brown oval shell, and thick, brown mossy fringe around its outer edge. The deepest of the pools is connected to the ocean by a channel through the rocks. Ocean waves create surges of water that rush through the channel. In the waters off shore and in the deeper pools, are tangled strands of brown kelp. The kelp’s ropelike stalks reach from the ocean floor up to the water’s surface, with short, rubbery, lasagna-like blades sticking off of it. Western snowy plovers are endangered small birds, with bodies about the size of a lime. They have light brown backs and wings, white breasts, narrow wings that end in a sharp point, and feather-less leathery brown legs and feet. Their rounded heads have a short black beak, and their feathers have a narrow black stripe across the forehead, a black horizontal stripe behind large black eyes, and a thin white ring around their necks. Below this ring are small dark rectangular patches; on one either side of their necks. The plovers scrape out shallow depressions in the sand where they lay their eggs. These are well camouflaged, and hard to see in the sand. Young snowy plovers are about the size of a person’s thumb when they hatch. They leave their nests within three hours of hatching, and begin to forage on their own. Plover parents work hard to keep their young safe. If a predator approaches their nest, they will pretend to be injured to lure the predator away. If their chicks are wandering when a predator appears, they will signal the chicks, which then flatten themselves against the sand to be less visible. If conditions are right, the Western snowy plovers may raise two or even three broods each year, in these vulnerable, sandy nests. These plovers were listed as threatened by the Fish and Wildlife Service on March 5, 1993. To help restore their population, the National Park Service closes several beaches on Santa Rosa and other Channel Islands during the breeding season.

data.title: Prisoner’s Harbor Hike
data.listingDescription: View the historic Prisoner’s Harbor buildings, a restored wetland, and search for the island scrub-jay (usually found in nearby trees or stream-side vegetation). Walk up the Navy Road for a short distance to get a nice view from above. Distance: .5 miles (round trip from Prisoner's Harbor) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: small harbor with a rocky beach and a pier.
images.title: Prisoner's Harbor, Santa Cruz Island
images.caption: Prisoner's Harbor, Santa Cruz Island

data.bodyText:
View the historic Prisoner’s Harbor buildings, a restored wetland, and search for the island scrub-jay (usually found in nearby trees or stream-side vegetation). Walk up the Navy Road for a short distance to get a nice view from above.

Distance: .5 miles (round trip from Prisoner's Harbor)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: The beach, ridges and hills that surround Prisoners Harbor provide a cultural landscape of great significance. This area includes; the historic Chumash village site of Xaxas (ha has), the pier and shoreline, stands of imported eucalyptus trees that edge the picnic area, a large brick warehouse, cattle corrals and scale building for weighing livestock, the site of the former ranch house, and a lookout cabin on a ridge above the harbor. Prisoners Beach is a secluded area of shoreline with a narrow strip of rock and cobble beach fading to vegetation. A picnic area with tables is placed near the shore.

data.title: Settles Bridge Canoe and Raft Launch
data.listingDescription: You'll have to carry your gear to the launch but it's well worth the haul. Launch your watercraft into the cold waters under the remains of the historic Settles Bridges.

images.altText: View looking upstream at the steps leading into the river with wooded shoreline in the distance.
images.title: Settles Bridge canoe, kayak, raft launch
images.caption: Steps leading to the water at Settles Bridge.

data.bodyText:
The Settles Bridge Launch provides access to the river for canoes, kayaks, and rafts. During the summer this launch can be crowded.

Water Quality

Be sure to check the Current Estimated E. coli count before starting your trip. If the count at Medlock Bridge is greater than 235 you have an increased risk of getting sick. Contact with the river is NOT recommended.

Water Release Schedule

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are influenced on a daily basis by water releases from Buford Dam. The water release schedule can be obtained by calling (770) 945-1466, or toll free 1-855-DAM-FLOW (1-855-326-3569), or visit their Hydropower Generating Schedule website. Besides showing the time for scheduled releases it also shows how many turbines will be operating and the current flow in cubic feet per second (cfs). It takes approximately 45 minutes for water released from Buford Dam to begin rising at Settles Bridge.

River Flow Rates

Water conditions on the Chattahoochee River are also influenced by the weather upstream of Settles Bridge. Regardless of whether the water is coming from a dam release or inclement weather upstream check the discharge/flow rate at the gaging station below Buford Dam. 

  • If Canoeing, Kayaking, or Stand Up Paddleboarding and the flow rate is over 4,000 cfs, cancel your trip. 
  • If Rafting and the flow rate is over 5,000 cfs, cancel your trip.
  • Float tubes are prohibited on this stretch of the river due to cold water temperatures.

Try These Floating Options

 

  • Lower Pool Park to Settles Bridge: 4.5 miles
  • Settles Bridge to McGinnis Bridge: 3.8 miles
  • Settles Bridge to Roger Bridge (Temporarily Closed): 6.7 miles
  • Settles Bridge to Abbotts Bridge: 8.3 miles
  • Settles Bridge to Medlock Bridge: 12.8 miles

data.title: Water Canyon Beach Hike
data.listingDescription: If the wind is not too strong, explore the wonderful 2-mile-long white sand beach. Beachcombing, birdwatching, swimming, snorkeling, fishing, windsurfing, and kayaking are all popular activities at Water Canyon Beach. The pier is not accessible from the beach unless there is a minus tide. Distance: 3 miles (round trip from pier to beach entrance) Difficulty: Easy

images.altText: White sand beach with sand dunes and aqua ocean.
images.title: Water Canyon Beach
images.caption: Water Canyon Beach, Santa Rosa Island

data.bodyText:
If the wind is not too strong, explore the wonderful 2-mile-long white sand beach. Beachcombing, birdwatching, swimming, snorkeling, fishing, windsurfing, and kayaking are all popular activities at Water Canyon Beach. The pier is not accessible from the beach unless there is a minus tide.

Distance: 3 miles (round trip from pier to beach entrance)
Difficulty: Easy
data.audioDescription: You are standing on a long curve of sandy beach, at the bottom of Water Canyon, near the middle of Bechers Bay. At your feet, scattered across the sand are tiny broken shells, driftwood, a few small rounded rocks, and broken pieces of kelp stalks and leaves. The ocean water near the shore is light turquois blue in color, growing darker blue further from the shore. On the inland side, the beach rises up into shallow, sandy dunes, mounds covered with small green plants. These curve up to meet the base of rock cliffs that tower almost 50 feet above the beach. Tall grass grows at the top of those cliffs. The cliffs follow the curve of Bechers Bay. If you are facing the ocean, to the left, or north, in the distance, is the wooden pier. It is a long narrow platform, supported of tall upright poles, extending a couple of hundred yards out into the ocean. To the right, or southeast, just past the top of the cliff, is a hillside covered with a dark green stand of Torrey pines. Beyond that is Skunk Point, a sandy spit of beach in the far distance.

data.audioDescription: Potato Harbor Trailhead is at the end of the upper campground. A moderate 5 mile hike along a trail that eventually hugs the very edge of the island provides a spectacular panoramic experience. From the canyon bottom near the upper campground, the trail branches to the right and continues along an old compacted dirt road that climbs to a plateau. The trail continues on to Potato Harbor, a very deeply sculpted narrow bay of bright blue green waters, named for its shape, the shape of a baking potato, with steep and rugged cliffs surrounding it on three sides.

Pilot Information

  • Operating Hours: The unattended airstrip is open 30 minutes before sunrise and closes minutes after sunset.
  • Pilot Booth: Access by using "Squawk VFR."
  • Parking: Aircraft may freely park in the tie-down area for 24 consecutive hours or 48 total hours over any 30-day period.

data.title: Gardner Junction Park
data.listingDescription: At Gardner Junction Park, the Oregon and California Trails split from the Santa Fe Trail. Each spring, west-bound travelers in Kansas would rush towards this junction and then take their "exit." Those heading to Santa Fe would continue southwest, while those heading to Oregon or California would turn and head northwest.

images.altText: Concrete pathway meandering through grass and shrub meadow with interpretive waysides and metal benches
images.caption: Gardner Junction Park Site Overview

data.bodyText:
At Gardner Junction Park, the Oregon and California Trails split from the Santa Fe Trail. Each spring, west-bound travelers in Kansas would rush towards this junction and then take their "exit." Those heading to Santa Fe would continue southwest, while those heading to Oregon or California would turn and head northwest. The travelers going to Oregon were primarily emigrants- people relocating from their homelands to new territories in the West. However, the travelers going to Santa Fe were primarily traders who were trading goods between the United States and Mexico. As such, travelers who took the southwest exit would pass by here again, while travelers who took the northwest exit would never return here.

Site Information

The junction is now a roadside park on U.S. 56. No physical traces of the junction remain, but the park does offer several interpretive waysides that tell its story, a walking path, and a historical marker. 

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Oregon National Historic Trail

California National Historic Trail

Santa Fe National Historic Trail
data.audioDescription:
Gardner Junction Park. 354 words

In front of the paved pullout and parking area is a brown sign the reads, "Gardner Junction, Santa Fe, California and Oregon Trails." Beside the parking area is a cement patio, lined by a low stone wall on the left and back sides. In the middle is a pavilion with a metal roof supported by four posts, covering three large signs. Behind the pavilion, against the wall is a metal bench. At the right side of the paved area a sidewalk makes a looping path about 100 yards long in total through meadow-like vegetation. At the far end of the loop are 4 more signs, two at each corner, and another metal bench.

The signs under the pavilion discuss nearby trail sites to the east, north-east and west, some of which are included in this app for the Oregon Trail.

The signs along the looping sidewalk cover other topics. One titled "Eye of the Needle" reads in part, "The historic junction of three great western frontier trails - the Santa Fe Trail, the Oregon Trail and the California Trail - is located approximately one-half mile to the north. To the southwest lay the Santa Fe Trail and to the northwest was the road to Oregon and California...Between the late 1830s and the early 1850s, as many as 200,000 emigrants may have passed through this gateway in order to start a new life in the Oregon Territory or to take a chance seeking their fortune in the gold fields of California. During this same period, thousands of freighters loaded with commodities were also rumbling through this junction heading to and from the markets at Santa Fe."

Another sign titled "Following Their Dreams" discusses the various types of travelers who followed these trails. A third sign, titled "Apprehension and Conflict," discusses the impact the large numbers of travelers had on the Indian Nations who lived in the Great Plains Region west of the Missouri River. The final sign is titled "From Prairie Schooners to Locomotives" and covers the decline of the trails as railroad lines spread and the transcontinental railroad was completed.

data.title: 100th Meridian Marker
data.listingDescription: The 100th degree of longitude long served as a boundary between nations: first between France and Spain; later as the boundary for the Louisiana Purchase between Spain and the U.S.; and finally between Mexico and the U.S. after 1821. Located in Dodge City, the meridian symbolizes the physical demarcation where the east ended and the west began.

data.title: Caches Monument
data.listingDescription: The Caches was a well known landmark and campsite on the Santa Fe Trail west of Dodge City, Kansas. Near here in 1822, a blizzard stopped Santa Fe–bound traders, forcing them to hide ("cache") their goods and come back for them later.

images.altText: A large stone marker with a plaque in a field.
images.title: Caches Monument
images.caption: The Caches Monument.

data.bodyText:
Near the Caches Monument, a blizzard stopped Santa Fe– bound traders in 1822. They dug holes, buried, and stored (cached) their goods until they returned from Taos six months later. The holes remained until recent times and became the landmark known as the “Caches” on the trail. The monument commemorates their campsite and nearby Ft Atkinson and Ft Mann. Near the Caches was also the original western terminus of the Wet/Dry Routes of the Santa Fe Trail. 

From here, you can easily visit the 100th Meridian Marker, Fort Dodge, Mulberry Creek Crossing, Boot Hill Museum, Fort Larned National Historic Site, Dodge City, and more.  

Site Information

Safety Considerations

Caches Monument is a large white monument on the side of a dirt road close to a highway. The monument is located within a rural environment with fields and farmlands.

data.title: Camp Grierson / Station Little Arkansas
data.listingDescription: Troops were deployed to Camp Grierson to help protect travelers on the Santa Fe Trail. Visible depressions in the earth are remnants of the dugouts constructed for troop protection.
data.bodyText:
Throughout the summer of 1864, the probability of conflicts between American Indians and travelers of the Santa Fe Trail increased dramatically west of the Little Arkansas. Troops were assigned to the Little Arkansas and the Stone Corral area in April 1865. It was called Station Little Arkansas. Company G, Third Wisconsin Cavalry, were the first troops to be stationed at the Stone Corral. By early May, 93 men were stationed at the post, most of them from the 2nd U. S. Volunteer Infantry. In June 1865, the 13th Missouri Cavalry was present. There were 185 enlisted men and five officers from the 13th Missouri Cavalry and the 2nd U. S. Volunteer Infantry. In June, 1865, four men were killed by American Indians near Station Little Arkansas. A cholera epidemic also claimed eight men at Station Little Arkansas. All were buried near the south end of the breastworks in the Cottonwood Grove Cemetery at Station Little Arkansas. Later the bodies were exhumed and moved to the Fort Leavenworth Cemetery in 1888 or 1889.

Peace talks and signing of peace treaties with the American Indians occurred in the fall of 1865. It appears troops were withdrawn from the Little Arkansas post late in 1865. This peaceful situation did not last long as soldiers were again stationed at the Stone Corral site in 1867. At this time the camp was called Camp Grierson, to honor Colonel Benjamin Grierson of the 10th Cavalry. In 1867, the camp was occupied from May to November by Company C of black troops of the 10th Cavalry. This company of some seventy troops constructed dugouts for protection from the American Indians and the weather in the riverbanks of the Little Arkansas. They erected breastworks above the dugouts for protection, which are still visible today.

During the summer of 2005, a stone was found in a nearby foundation of a fire damaged house that was inscribed with the name of Andrew Welsch of Co. E, 13th MO Cavalry. This unit was at Station Little Arkansas in 1865.

Site Information 

Safety Considerations

Santa Fe Trail Association Little Arkansas Crossing Brochure

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

data.title: Cimarron Crossing Park
data.listingDescription: Cimarron Crossing Park is located where the Ranch at Cimarron Crossing once stood. The ranch sat at the junction of the Mountain and Cimarron Routes of the Santa Fe Trail and provided travelers with accommodations, supplies, and protection. Not only will you get a taste of history at Cimarron Crossing Park, but you will also be able to have some fun on the ball fields and playground.

images.credit: NPS Image, Exhibit described in content.
images.altText: An illustration of a pioneer age frontier fort. Text is described in content."
images.title: Cimarron Ranch Wayside photo
images.caption: The Cimarron Ranch exhibit

data.bodyText:
The Santa Fe Trail passed by where Cimarron Crossing Park is now, bringing people and goods along the trading route. Just to the south, the Arkansas River formed the border with Mexico. Traders and travelers required accommodations, supplies, and protection. The Ranch at Cimarron Crossing was established in 1866 by William and Frank Hartwell and several other investors to meet those needs. Later, it was operated by Robert Wright, one of the founders of Dodge City, and A.J. Anthony.  At full force there were 12 armed men at the Cimarron Crossing station.

The ranch sat in the midst of a vast open plain, covered only with cactus on the higher ground and with grass in the river bottoms as high as a man on horseback. Buffalo could be seen in any direction, and for an hour at a time the river might be heard roaring in the night from the crossing of great herds. Wolves could be heard from darkness until dawn.

Many Native Americans, such as the Cheyenne, viewed settlements such as the ranch as intrusions onto their homelands. Tension between settlers, traders, and the military increased, including an attack on a wagon train crossing here in June 1867. In 1868, the ranch was abandoned due to the continuous threat of attack from Native Americans.

Site Information

The Cimarron City Park is one of the most beautiful parks in Southwest Kansas. Located on the banks of the Arkansas River, the park plays host to a variety of community functions. The park also has two baseball/softball diamonds and a Tee-ball field. A new walking track has been added around the park that is a half-mile in length.

  •  Cimarron Crossing Ranch Interpretive Exhibit:


"Building Materials: The closest timber for building was 20 miles away. Much of the ranch was turf, including the roof. The roof was laid first of poles, then a layer of buffalo hides and gunny sacks and upon this an eight inch course of dirt or sod. 

The Ranch Complex : Every part of the building was not only secure against fire and weather, but also proof against bullets. It included: the kaavl (corral) was 100 steps square, the main building was 40 by 16 feet and joined a two-story round tower, the corner of the kaavl was a stage driver's lobby and similar tower, the remainder of this enclosure furnished stables for mules, enough water in barrels to withstand a siege, walls that were two feet thick."

 

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

Located on the banks of the Arkansas River, the park plays host to a variety of community functions. The park also has two baseball/softball diamonds and a Tee-ball field. A new walking track has been added around the park that is a half-mile in length.

data.title: Coronado Cross Park
data.listingDescription: At Coronado Cross Park, you will be near where Santa Fe Trail travelers faced an important decision. Would they take the Wet or Dry Route of the Santa Fe Trail? Enjoy views of prairie out to the Arkansas River that Santa Fe Trail would have seen as they made their decision.
data.bodyText:
Near here, eastbound trail travelers made a choice between two routes. The Wet Route, also known as the river route, water road, or lower road, followed the north bank of the Arkansas River and provided a sure source of water. The Dry Route, also called the ridge or ridge road, followed an upland course that was shorter in miles than the Wet Route, but could lack water

The Dry Route and the Wet Route merged to the east of Fort Dodge. Westbound travelers next had to decide whether to continue along the north side of the Arkansas River to take the Mountain Route or to cross the river and take the Cimarron Route. Mulberry Creek Crossing was the first option, although crossings farther west were often preferred.

Coronado Cross Park is named for Francisco Vasquez de Coronado, a Spanish nobleman and the first Christian serv

Site Information

At Coronado Cross Park you will see a towering concrete cross and a view of unplowed prairie across to the Arkansas River.

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

data.title: Council Oak in Council Grove
data.listingDescription: The Council Oak received its name from a council that was ostensibly held under this tree on August 10, 1825. This council, which was attended by three U.S. commissioners and the chiefs of the Great and Little Osage Indians, resulted in a treaty that - in return for an $800 payment - gave Americans and Hispanics free passage along the Santa Fe Trail through Osage territory.

images.altText: A large tree stump under a red tarp.
images.title: Council Oak
images.caption: Council Oak

data.bodyText:
The Council Oak received its name from a council that was ostensibly held under this tree on August 10, 1825. This council, which was attended by three U.S. commissioners and the chiefs of the Great and Little Osage Indians, resulted in a treaty that - in return for an $800 payment - gave Americans and Hispanics free passage along the Santa Fe Trail through Osage territory. This meeting was also the namesake of Council Grove, a trailside community that was founded in the late 1840s, because of the mile-wide grove of hardwood timber in the area.

A protective canopy east of the Neosho River bridge protects the stump of the Council Oak. Before it blew down in a windstorm in 1958, the oak was approximately 70 feet high and measured 16 feet around.

Site Information 

Safety Considerations

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

data.title: DAR Marker near Dodge House Hotel
data.listingDescription: Near the Dodge House Hotel in Dodge City you can visit one of the earliest markers of the Santa Fe Trail. In the early 20th century, the Daughters of the American Revolution put up a series of markers so that the Santa Fe Trail may be remembered. One of these stands near the Dodge House Hotel.
data.bodyText:
The DAR marker near the Dodge House Hotel is one of a series of markers the Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR) put up in the early 20th century to mark the Santa Fe Trail. The Kansas Daughters began the work in 1902 to ensure the preservation of the Santa Fe Trail and its important place in American History. By 1906, they had enough money for 86 markers made of red granite boulders. From here, they worked with the communities along the Trail to place and dedicate the markers. Soon, the DAR chapters of Missouri, Colorado, and New Mexico followed suit. Had it not been for the hard work and dedication of the women of the DAR, the Santa Fe Trail might have been lost to history.

Site Information

A red granite boulder that reads "Santa Fe Trail 1822 - 1872 Marked by the Daughters of the American Revolution and the Sate of Kansas 1906."

Safety Considerations

More Site Information

Santa Fe National Historic Trail

data.title: Davis Segment & Ruts
data.listingDescription: Thousands of travelers created these ruts, deepening them just a bit with each passing. Well-defined trail ruts near the Davis Segment/Ruts can be seen directly from County Road 16.
